title: Session 1: Introduction to Anxiety
description: In this part of the program, you will read a series of pages about the topics below. Pay attention to the pages because after you have read all of the pages, you will be asked questions about them.
There will be a Continue button at the end of each paragraph.
When you finish reading the information you will be asked questions about it.
The score, located in the top right corner, shows the number of times you answered a question correctly on the first try.

text: Anxiety, one of the most basic human emotions, is a normal and common experience. At one time or another, all of us are likely to feel “stressed out”; worried about finances, health, or family; fearful in potentially dangerous situations (e.g., on a ladder or before an operation); or concerned about what other people think.
Anxious responses usually consist of a variety of changes in one’s thoughts, bodily reactions, feelings, and behavior, such as these:

questions.question: The emotion anxiety is characterized by changes in thoughts, bodily reactions, feelings, and behavior (T).

text: Anxiety is a useful emotion, especially from an evolutionary point of view. Shaped by natural selection, anxiety helps us survive dangerous situations. For example, if a Neanderthal man is attacked by a saber-toothed tiger, he may be most likely to survive by fleeing and avoiding the tiger in fear. By increasing one’s ability to detect danger and preparing one’s body for fight or flight, anxiety helps people manage threats to the lives, health, or well-being of themselves or others. A moderate level of anxiety increases attention, concentration, and performance.

scenario.title: Avoiding an Accident
scenario.statement: Driving home from work, Malik suddenly sees a child dart into the street in front of his car. Malik slams on the brakes and swerves, just missing the child. As he pulls over, Malik’s heart is beating furiously, and he is breathless, sweating, and shaking. He could have killed that child. Only after several long minutes is he able to continue his drive home.

text: Of course, today it is unlikely that we will be confronted by saber-toothed tigers on the street, but there are other situations in which anxiety is still reasonable. For example, in the scenario above, Malik nearly had an accident and could have injured himself and a child. His anxious reaction to this situation is reasonable in that it helped keep both him and the child alive. As we can see in this example, the dangerous situation changed, but the usefulness of anxiety remained.

Although anxiety is useful in many situations, it ceases to be useful when it arises in the absence of a real threat or when it becomes excessive. When anxiety dominates people’s daily lives and interferes with their abilities to fulfill work, school, or family responsibilities, anxiety might not be adaptive anymore. In these cases, it may be difficult to control the occurrence and duration of anxiety, even if one knows there is no real danger; such anxiety may be considered impairing.
